results.title: These were the days: Victoria revisited
results.creator_credit: David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Takes the audience around Victoria to see the preserving of history in country towns. The port of Echuca where the paddle streamer Canberra runs up the Murray River; Sovereign Hill in Ballarat; Burke Museum at Beechworth; The Museum of Agricultural Machinery at Warracknabeal; The Gippsland Folk Museum at Moe; Coal Creek mining town at Korumburra and the Pioneer Settlement.

results.title: These three
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: This cinematic masterpiece, directed with enormous sensitivity by William Wyler, tells the story of two women (Merle Oberon and Miriam Hopkins) who fall in love with the same man (Joel McCrea) and the damage to their lives that can be caused to all three by the malicious lies of a spiteful teenage schoolgirl (Bonita Granville). This powerful story of gossip and suspicion was based on Lillian Hellman’s controversial Broadway success “The Children’s Hour.” The appearance of Walter Brennan as the local taxi driver brings the only light relief to such a dramatic film and the outstanding performance of Bonita Granville was nominated for an Academy Award.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company

results.title: These things I still question
results.creator_credit: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Saunders questions the things in his life that he didn’t understand, like why his dad was treated differently, why he couldn’t play with the white kids and why people just let this happen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: These are scouts
results.brief_description: Shows what it means to be a scout in 1971 and gives details of how a local Scout Group is run. Included are many of the Movement’s activities such as camping, gliding, boating, caving, and overseas travel.

results.title: Thermometers: how they help us
results.brief_description:
Demonstrates the basic principle that liquids expand when heated and contract when cooled. Shows how a thermometer is built and used and depicts different types of thermometers.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Thermodynamics
results.brief_description: Animation is used to show molecular action in iron which has been heated, and the relation between temperature of the iron and the amount of molecular action.

results.title: Thermionic valve
results.brief_description: The thermionic valve makes possible the control of energy that is released when electricity is liberated from a metal. The thermionic valve is the radio valve - the forerunner to mini valves, thence the transistor.
results.description: The thermionic valve makes possible the control of energy that is released when electricity is liberated from a metal. The thermionic valve is the radio valve - the forerunner to mini valves, thence the transistor.

results.title: Thermal wonderland
results.creator_credit: Stanhope Andrews and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Aerial view of Rotorua and the volcanic formation of the surrounding country. Geysers, mud pools, terraces, hot springs, and the color of the rock formation in the thermal district. Glimpses of Whakarewarewa, Rotomahana, Wairakei, and the Waikato River with the Huka Falls.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanhope Andrews and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Therese Raquin = the Adulteress
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carne, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
Therese, the bored, unhappy and love-starved wife of a weak, flabby and petulant railway worker, becomes involved with a handsome Italian truck driver, an affair that leads to murder and blackmail. For what was to be his last notable film, Carne updated Emile Zola’s famous novel of destructive sensual passion, and set it in the bleak provincial back streets of Lyons. It is redolent with brooding atmosphere but, somehow, it is a cold film in which the leads are efficient rather than passionate, leaving the acting honours to Sylvie as Therese’s crippled, unpleasant and vigilant mother-in-law. The famous version of this tale, made in 1928 by Jacques Feyder is, alas, no longer extant. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Robert Hakim, Raymond Hakim ; director, Marcel Carne ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Roger Hubert ; music, Maurice Thiriet ; costumes, Mayo.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Raf Vallone, Sylvie, Jacques Duby.
